title.narrative: Improving food security for vulnerable IDPs, Returnees and Host Communities in South Kordofan State

description.narrative: South Kordofan is historically known to be a surplus-cereal-production area. Agriculture and livestock herding are the main livelihood activities of the population. Conflict has severely affected agriculture, livestock and other social services, resulting in overall destruction and disruption of people’s livelihoods leaving them with no or very little means of survival. This project aims at assisting the vulnerable war-affected households of IDPs, returnees and poor host communities with agricultural inputs and livestock services to enable them to restore their farming activities and produce their own food during the coming season and protect their livestock against major epidemic diseases. The project has two approvals; Cycle one was running between 04/11/2018 - 30/10/2019 with an extension of 3 months. Cycle 2 approval will cover project intervention from March 2020 to 31 August 2020. This intervention will cover gaps that were not covered in year 2019-2020 interventions mainly construction of 5 class rooms , provision of seating units for 5 class and support establishment of 2 saving and loan groups . The project main goal is to improve livelihood and food security for the IDPs, Returnees and vulnerable host communities in Abu-karshola and Algoz localities/South Kordofan State(SKS). There are a number of outcomes this project seeks to achieve; 1.Food security and living status of the targeted communities are improved 2.1000 pastoralist families have access to livestock veterinary services 3.The family income of 60 targeted women and men is increased, and their living status improved. 4.Women, men and children in Aloz locality- Debibat and Kurure villages minimize exposure to disaster risks through adaptation of appropriate disaster preparedness and climate adaptation measures. 5.School aged children in Abkarshola have improved access to formal education The project targets to reach out to 1000 HHs in 9 villages
